p.s: The excerpt from Part Two, Chapter 6 of the novel The Tortilla Curtain by T. C. Boyle and published in 1995, deals with one of DelaneysDelaney's first visible and direct racist actions towards illegal Mexicans.
The protagonist Delaney Mossbacher sees a Mexican at the lawn of his friends the Cherrystones.
Since he knows that the inhabitants aren't home and because of the mansman's ethnicity he walks up to him to confront him.
Delaney realises that he had seen him before already and recognises him as the person, who has camped in the canyon and threatened his wife Kyra.
The Mexican tries to explain that he is working, but due to his poor englishEnglish Delaney doesn't understand him.
Because of all the prejudices the protagonist holds and the workers non obidient behaviour DelaneysDelaney's anger increases to the point where he becomes physically touchy.
The Mexican frees his wrist from the hold, hands Delaney a flyer and leaves to continue his work.

The white americanAmerican is shocked when he realises that he wrongfully judged the immigrant and sees that the flyer is about and invetationinvitation to a community meeting discussing their safety and security.
Delaney lives together with his second wife, Kyra and her son in the Arroyo Blanco Estates in California near the Topanga Canyon.
Even though the community there is predominantly racist and against illegal immigration the protagonist saw himself as a liberal humanist and a role model in terms of his moral believesbeliefs.

Influenced by several events like a car accident with a Mexican he is responsible for easily being manipulated and influenced by his openly racist friend Jack Jardine, his wife feeling threatened by Mexicans and one of his wifeswife's dogs being caught by a coyote makes him feel anxious, unsafe and developedevelops xenophobia especially towards Mexicans.

Even though he already showed signs of convert racism at the beginning of the plot and conscience and rationality usually overweightedoverweighed his fears he undergoes a big change strongly seen in his main trait of ambivalence.
Putting the excerpt in the context the Mossbachers already have a fence around their yard because of a fear that the coyote might break in again and take their other dog too.
However the community is thinking of putting a wall around them.

Todd Sweet, another inhabitant theirthere is against that campaign and reaches out to Delaney because he is known for writing columns about the flora and fauna of the Topanga Canyon and asks him to help him write flyers to change the communityscommunity's mind, but he never gets in touch with him.
Later on, after the excerpt the wall is built and they become a gated community, which Delaney first dislikes but then approves.
This excerpt is one of DelaneysDelaney's many stations of development he undergoes in the novel, but one that shows his racist thoughts and prejudices in clear action for the first time.
